sn2.29:4.2: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
sn2.29:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn2.29:5.1: “Sir, who on earth would not like Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?
sn2.29:5.18: Who on earth would not like Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”
sn2.29:6.1: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!
sn2.29:6.2: Who on earth would not like Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”
sn2.29:6.3: And the Buddha repeated all of Ānanda’s terms of praise.
sn2.29:7.1: While this praise of Sāriputta was being spoken, the god Susīma approached the Buddha, escorted by a large assembly of gods.
sn2.29:7.2: He bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.29:8.1: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
sn2.29:8.2: Who on earth would not like Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”
sn2.29:8.3: And he too repeated all the terms of praise of Sāriputta, adding:
sn2.29:9.1: “For I too, sir, whenever I go to an assembly of gods, frequently hear the same terms of praise.”
sn2.29:10.1: While this praise of Sāriputta was being spoken, the gods of Susīma’s assembly—uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness—generated a rainbow of bright colors.
sn2.29:11.1: Suppose there was a gem of lapus lazuli that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, with expert workmanship. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.
sn2.29:11.2: In the same way, the gods of Susīma’s assembly … generated a rainbow of bright colors.
sn2.29:12.1: Suppose there was an ornament of rare gold, fashioned by a skilled smith, expertly wrought in the forge. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.
sn2.29:12.2: In the same way, the gods of Susīma’s assembly … generated a spectrum of bright colors.
sn2.29:13.1: Suppose that after the rainy season the sky was clear and cloudless. As the night fades, the Morning Star shines and glows and radiates.
sn2.29:13.2: In the same way, the gods of Susīma’s assembly … generated a spectrum of bright colors.
sn2.29:14.1: Suppose that after the rainy season the sky was clear and cloudless. As the sun rises, it would dispel all the darkness from the sky as it shines and glows and radiates.
sn2.29:14.2: In the same way, the gods of Susīma’s assembly … generated a spectrum of bright colors.
sn2.29:15.1: Then the god Susīma recited this verse about Venerable Sāriputta in the Buddha’s presence.
sn2.29:16.1: “He’s considered to be an astute person,
sn2.29:16.4: the seer shines in the Teacher’s praise!”
sn2.29:17.1: Then the replied to Susīma with this verse about Venerable Sāriputta:
sn2.29:18.1: “He’s considered to be an astute person,
sn2.29:18.4: developed and well-tamed, he bides his time.”
